articles.headline: Fed Dissenters Increasingly Vocal About Inflation Fears
articles.snippet: The group believes the Federal Reserve has nearly exhausted its ability to repair damage caused by the recession.
articles.abstract: The group believes the Federal Reserve has nearly exhausted its ability to repair damage caused by the recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An increasingly vocal minority of Federal Reserve officials want the central bank to retreat more quickly from its stimulus campaign, arguing that the bank has largely exhausted its ability to improve economic conditions.

articles.headline: Ex-Governor Points the Finger at His Wife in a Virginia Trial
articles.snippet: Bob McDonnell, the Virginia ex-governor, began the political sales job of his life Wednesday, testifying to stave off conviction on corruption charges.
articles.abstract: Bob McDonnell, the Virginia ex-governor, began the political sales job of his life Wednesday, testifying to stave off conviction on corruption charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Beginning the political sales job of his life, Bob McDonnell, the former Virginia governor and once rising Republican star, was called Wednesday afternoon to the witness stand, where he began to lay out the unusual defense that he could not have conspired corruptly with his wife because they were too estranged to manage it.

articles.headline: Police Cameras Can Shed Light, but Raise Privacy Concerns
articles.snippet: Cameras worn by officers are being deployed in a rising number of police departments across the country, in some cases exposing problem officers.
articles.abstract: Cameras worn by officers are being deployed in a rising number of police departments across the country, in some cases exposing problem officers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael Brown, the unarmed teenager who was shot during an encounter with police in Ferguson, Mo., on Aug. 9, was recorded by a convenience store surveillance camera a few minutes before he was killed, according to police. Then, just after he died, a picture of his body was snapped by a Twitter user who claims to have seen the shooting.

articles.headline: In Raid to Save Foley and Other Hostages, U.S. Found None
articles.snippet: A Special Operations team failed to rescue the journalist James Foley and other Americans held in Syria during a secret mission earlier this summer.
articles.abstract: A Special Operations team failed to rescue the journalist James Foley and other Americans held in Syria during a secret mission earlier this summer.
articles.lead_paragraph: EDGARTOWN, Mass. — A secret nighttime military mission authorized by President Obama to rescue Americans held captive in Syria failed early this summer when a team of two dozen Delta Force commandos raided an oil refinery in the northern part of the country but found after a firefight with Islamic militants that there were no hostages to be saved, administration officials said Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: New Era in Safety When Cars Talk to One Another
articles.snippet: A government-sponsored pilot program in Ann Arbor, Mich., is exploring the benefits that occur when vehicles can talk with one another, and their surroundings.
articles.abstract: A government-sponsored pilot program in Ann Arbor, Mich., is exploring the benefits that occur when vehicles can talk with one another, and their surroundings.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — A driver moves along in traffic, the forward view blocked by a truck or a bend in the road. Suddenly, up ahead, someone slams on the brake. Tires screech.

articles.headline: Texas Car Lender Is Accused of Distortion in Subprime Inquiry
articles.snippet: First Investors Financial Services Group is accused of giving credit reporting agencies flawed data about thousands of car buyers.
articles.abstract: First Investors Financial Services Group is accused of giving credit reporting agencies flawed data about thousands of car buyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The cycle is a familiar one on Wall Street. First comes a lending boom. And then, after the abuses and excesses of a bubble, there is the government crackdown.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Bank of America Expected to Settle Huge Mortgage Case for $16.65 Billion
articles.snippet: Prosecutors are also preparing a separate civil case against Angelo Mozilo, the man who came to embody the risk-taking in subprime mortgage loans.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors are also preparing a separate civil case against Angelo Mozilo, the man who came to embody the risk-taking in subprime mortgage loans.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Anger, Hurt and Moments of Hope in Ferguson
articles.snippet: Ever since a white police officer fatally shot an unarmed black youth two Saturdays ago, this St. Louis suburb has been deeply troubled.
articles.abstract: Ever since a white police officer fatally shot an unarmed black youth two Saturdays ago, this St. Louis suburb has been deeply troubled.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — The long, white bus emerged from a dark side street earlier in the week. Through the tinted windows, people on the street could see flashing lights and bodies moving to a beat. It was a party bus.

articles.headline: Before Killing James Foley, ISIS Demanded Ransom From U.S.
articles.snippet: The militants had pressed the United States to provide several million dollars for the release of James Foley, an American journalist killed in retaliation for recent airstrikes in Iraq.
articles.abstract: The militants had pressed the United States to provide several million dollars for the release of James Foley, an American journalist killed in retaliation for recent airstrikes in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kneeling in the dirt in a desert somewhere in the Middle East, James Foley lost his life this week at the hands of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria. Before pulling out the knife used to decapitate him, his masked executioner explained that he was killing the 40-year-old American journalist in retaliation for the recent United States’ airstrikes against the terrorist group in Iraq.

articles.headline: Israel Kills 3 Top Hamas Leaders as Latest Fighting Turns Its Way
articles.snippet: The latest round of fighting appears to have given Israel the upper hand in a conflict that has already outlasted all expectations and is increasingly becoming a war of attrition.
articles.abstract: The latest round of fighting appears to have given Israel the upper hand in a conflict that has already outlasted all expectations and is increasingly becoming a war of attrition.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Hamas is the party that keeps extending this summer’s bloody battle in the Gaza Strip, repeatedly breaking temporary truces and vowing to endlessly fire rockets into Israel until its demands are met. But the latest round of fighting appears to have given Israel the upper hand in a conflict that has already outlasted all expectations and is increasingly becoming a war of attrition.

articles.headline: National Guard Is Pulling Out of Ferguson as Tensions Ease
articles.snippet: Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri said that the situation had “greatly improved.” In Washington, federal prosecutors face obstacles bringing civil rights charges in the shooting of Michael Brown.
articles.abstract: Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri said that the situation had “greatly improved.” In Washington, federal prosecutors face obstacles bringing civil rights charges in the shooting of Michael Brown.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — Gov. Jay Nixon ordered the Missouri National Guard to begin a withdrawal from this small city on Thursday, signaling that the authorities believed they had largely restored order after nearly two weeks of unrest set off by the police shooting of an unarmed, 18-year-old black man.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman, Matt Apuzzo and Marc Santora

articles.headline: Bank of America’s $16 Billion Mortgage Settlement Less Painful Than It Looks
articles.snippet: Bank of America’s financial burden for the settlement may not exceed $12 billion — certainly a large amount, but one significantly less than the number the government trumpets.
articles.abstract: Bank of America’s financial burden for the settlement may not exceed $12 billion — certainly a large amount, but one significantly less than the number the government trumpets.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said on Thursday that it had so far recovered nearly $37 billion from big banks for their role in selling shoddy mortgages before the financial crisis.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Michael Corkery
